Award.AbstractNarration:
Metabolomics is the study of low molecular weight molecules found within cells and biological systems. It has emerged for deciphering the complex time-related concentration, activity and flux of metabolites in biological samples. Multiple analytical platforms such as liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy have been used in metabolomics. Unlike other analytical platforms, the comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry system provides a much increased separation capacity, chemical selectivity and sensitivity for the analysis of metabolites. The aim of this project is to infer metabolic networks from the measurements of metabolites using this high-throughput comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry system. To achieve a high accuracy metabolic network construction, an innovative peak detection algorithm will be first developed for simultaneous baseline removal, smoothing and peak picking steps, as well as the statistical assessment of peak confidence level. The investigators will then develop an innovative peak alignment algorithm based on global comparison using point matching algorithm as well as considering measurement error and outlier detection. Once an accurate alignment peak table is created, metabolic networks will be created using Bayesian ensemble method, which is Bayesian model averaging, to find meaningful pairwise interactions and associations among sets of metabolite peaks as well as to account for uncertainty of network complexity. In particular, the pathway information will be incorporated into network constructions for weighting each network constructed by several different approaches.

The comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry platform can not only leverage the peak capacity issue in current metabolomics, but also brings much improved chemical selectivity and sensitivity for metabolomics analyses. The developed statistical and computational approaches will lead to new methodology for data pre-processing and metabolic network construction for the analysis of high-throughput data. The metabolic network construction system developed from this project will enable identification of consistent metabolite mechanisms and pathways for numerous organisms and diseases in real time. Thus this research will have broader impacts for biomedical research, medicine and public health. The methods developed in this research can also be applied to the analysis of liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry based metabolomics data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metabolomics is the study of low molecular weight molecules found within cells and biological systems, deciphering the complex time-related concentration, activity and flux of metabolites in biological samples. This project aimed to infer metabolic networks from the measurements of metabolites using a high-throughput comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry system that, unlike other analytical platforms, provides a much increased separation capacity, chemical selectivity and sensitivity for the analysis of metabolites. In order to construct a metabolic network with high accuracy, it is also critical to prepare the input data by preprocessing experimental data. Thus, we also planned to develop novel statistical methodologies for two important preprocessing, peak detection and peak alignment.

The first preprocessing of the data generated by two dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry is to detect peaks, which ideally represent a compound or metabolite. Numerous methods have been proposed to improve the performance of peak detection on mass spectrometry data analysis, but most of them relied on independent processes, baseline removal, smoothing and peak picking, which will introduce unwanted biases and noise into the data, causing an increment of false discovery rate. Thus, we proposed and developed a novel peak detection method to render these steps simultaneously. We also further incorporated two innovative methods, mass spectrum similarity-based peak detection and generalized Normal-Gamma-Bernoulli model-based peak region finding.

Multiple data for the same biological sample are often generated to detect biological variations by multiple experiments. To align multiple data into one data set, peak alignment should be performed. We have been developed several innovative peak alignment algorithms using both distance and similarity algorithms. During these developments, we recognized that current algorithms have one critic to be resolved that they don’t utilize the global shape information between two experimental data. To deal with this issue, we used point matching algorithms that have been used in brain image matching processes. An advantage of point matching algorithms is that it incorporates the shape information of each brain and then matches two different images. But, current point matching algorithms use only distance information, so we combined mass spectral similarities as prior into point matching algorithms and improved the performance of peak alignment.

Using the preprocessed data by our two developed algorithms, we developed a novel algorithm to construct metabolic networks. In particular, we first compared several existing algorithms to construct metabolic networks while developing new methodologies, such as, principal component regression- and independent component regression-based methods. Although we could show that our previously developed algorithms achieve a better performance than others in metabolomics, we also realized that the performance deeply depends on the complexity of network structure that will not be able to infer before network construction or without true values. To resolve this uncertainty, we developed an ensemble approach by combining all results generated from multiple construction methods. By doing so, we could observe that the developed method mostly achieves the average performance compared to other single methods and, for some occasions, performs better than single methods.

Education was a key component of the project. A total of 6 graduate students (2 MS and 4 PhD students) participated in our project. Of these, 40% (2 PhD students) were female. All students worked on different subprojects and developed statistical methods to construct metabolite association networks. Our students published several peer-reviewed journal papers, conference abstracts and conference papers with the support of our project. 


Last Modified: 04/19/2017
Modified by: Seong Ho Kim
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Metabolomics is the study of low molecular weight molecules found within cells and biological systems, deciphering the complex time-related concentration, activity and flux of metabolites in biological samples. This project aimed to infer metabolic networks from the measurements of metabolites using a high-throughput comprehensive two-dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry system that, unlike other analytical platforms, provides a much increased separation capacity, chemical selectivity and sensitivity for the analysis of metabolites. In order to construct a metabolic network with high accuracy, it is also critical to prepare the input data by preprocessing experimental data. Thus, we also planned to develop novel statistical methodologies for two important preprocessing, peak detection and peak alignment. The first preprocessing of the data generated by two dimensional gas chromatography mass spectrometry is to detect peaks, which ideally represent a compound or metabolite. Numerous methods have been proposed to improve the performance of peak detection on mass spectrometry data analysis, but most of them relied on independent processes, baseline removal, smoothing and peak picking, which will introduce unwanted biases and noise into the data, causing an increment of false discovery rate. Thus, we proposed and developed a novel peak detection method to render these steps simultaneously. Multiple data for the same biological sample are often generated to detect biological variations by multiple experiments. To align multiple data into one data set, peak alignment should be performed. We have been developed several innovative peak alignment algorithms using both distance and similarity algorithms. During these developments, we recognized that current algorithms have one critic to be resolved that they don?t utilize the global shape information between two experimental data. An advantage of point matching algorithms is that it incorporates the shape information of each brain and then matches two different images. But, current point matching algorithms use only distance information, so we combined mass spectral similarities as prior into point matching algorithms and improved the performance of peak alignment. Using the preprocessed data by our two developed algorithms, we developed a novel algorithm to construct metabolic networks. In particular, we first compared several existing algorithms to construct metabolic networks while developing new methodologies, such as, principal component regression- and independent component regression-based methods. Although we could show that our previously developed algorithms achieve a better performance than others in metabolomics, we also realized that the performance deeply depends on the complexity of network structure that will not be able to infer before network construction or without true values. To resolve this uncertainty, we developed an ensemble approach by combining all results generated from multiple construction methods. By doing so, we could observe that the developed method mostly achieves the average performance compared to other single methods and, for some occasions, performs better than single methods. Education was a key component of the project. A total of 6 graduate students (2 MS and 4 PhD students) participated in our project. Of these, 40% (2 PhD students) were female. All students worked on different subprojects and developed statistical methods to construct metabolite association networks. Our students published several peer-reviewed journal papers, conference abstracts and conference papers with the support of our project. Last Modified: 04/19/2017 Submitted by: Seong Ho Kim
